title: R44693
content: The FMLA requires covered employers to grant up to 12 workweeks of leave for various reasons, including the birth or adoption of a child, caring for a family member with a serious health condition, the employee's own health condition, and military exigencies. Additionally, eligible employees can receive up to 26 workweeks of leave to care for a covered military servicemember with a serious injury or illness. Employees must meet certain criteria to be eligible for FMLA leave. The FMLA provides up to 12 workweeks of leave for various reasons, including caring for a family member with a serious health condition or military exigencies. Eligibility criteria include working for a covered employer, having 1,250 hours of service in the past 12 months, and working at a location with 50 or more employees within 75 miles. Public agencies are covered regardless of staffing levels, but employees must meet the worksite coverage requirement. The FMLA has been amended multiple times since 1993 to cover legislative branch employees, create military family leave entitlement, and modify eligibility requirements. Several bills in the 114th Congress aimed to expand FMLA entitlements and modify employee eligibility. Currently, eligible employees can take 12 workweeks of FMLA leave for family and medical needs. Some proposals in the 114th Congress aimed to expand FMLA entitlements, including creating new leave categories like Parental Involvement and Family Wellness Leave. H.R. 5518 would have allowed eligible employees up to 24 hours of leave in a 12-month period for school conferences, medical appointments, or caring for family members. H.R. 5535 would have provided similar entitlements for Parental Involvement Leave. H.R. 5535 proposes Parental Involvement Leave, allowing eligible employees up to 48 hours of leave in a 12-month period to attend school conferences or activities for their child or grandchild. Employees must give a 7-day notice to their employers before taking this leave. The 114th Congress considered proposals to expand qualifying uses of FMLA leave, including bereavement, domestic violence-related needs, family involvement, and medical needs for veterans. The 114th Congress considered proposals to expand FMLA leave entitlement for bereavement, domestic violence needs, family involvement, and medical needs for veterans. Proposals included using FMLA for the death of a son or daughter, parent, or sibling, but not for the death of a spouse. Employees could also use FMLA for domestic violence-related needs and limited family involvement. S. 473 proposed granting employees limited use of existing FMLA leave for family involvement, including school activities and medical appointments for family members. Employees could use up to 24 hours of leave in a 12-month period. H.R. 5165 would have allowed FMLA leave for hospital care or medical services for veterans with service-connected disabilities. H.R. 5165 proposed expanding FMLA leave entitlement for family involvement purposes, including hospital care for veterans with service-connected disabilities rated at 30% or higher. It aimed to broaden the set of relationships for which an employee may use family leave and amend definitions related to the current entitlement. The FMLA allows for leave related to the arrival of a new son or daughter, a family member's serious health condition, military exigency, and military caregiver leave. Proposed legislative changes aimed to expand caregiving purposes for FMLA leave, including amending the definition of son or daughter. Proposed legislative changes aimed to expand caregiving purposes for FMLA leave, including adding new family members such as domestic partners, adult children, parents-in-law, grandparents, and siblings for caregiving purposes related to a family member's serious health condition or the arrival of a new son or daughter. Proposed legislative changes aim to expand FMLA leave for caregiving purposes by adding new family members like domestic partners, adult children, parents-in-law, grandparents, and siblings for various caregiving situations. This includes adding these family members for needs related to a family member's serious health condition, military exigency leave, and military caregiver leave. The proposed legislative changes aim to expand FMLA leave for caregiving purposes by adding new family members like domestic partners, adult children, parents-in-law, grandparents, and siblings for various caregiving situations. This includes adding these family members for needs related to a family member's serious health condition, military exigency leave, and military caregiver leave. H.R. 5701 and S. 473 proposed adding additional family members such as adult children, grandchildren, and grandparents to broaden FMLA definitions. The 114th Congress considered legislation to clarify FMLA-qualifying uses of leave by amending definitions of son or daughter and serious health condition. The proposed legislative changes aim to expand FMLA leave by amending definitions of son or daughter and serious health condition. The amendments would include children of any age and a child of a domestic partner, broadening the applicability of leave. The definition of serious health condition includes inpatient care or continuing treatment by a health care provider. The proposed legislative changes aim to expand FMLA leave by amending definitions of son or daughter and serious health condition. S. 2584 and H.R. 4616 would specify that recovery from surgery related to organ donation can be considered a serious health condition, but inpatient care or continuing treatment by a health care provider would still need to be met for eligibility. The 114th Congress considered proposals to amend general eligibility requirements for FMLA leave and specific worker groups. The 114th Congress considered proposals to expand FMLA leave eligibility requirements, including reducing the minimum number of employees within 75 miles of an employee's worksite and amending the hours-of-service requirement. The 114th Congress considered proposals to expand FMLA leave eligibility requirements, including reducing the minimum number of employees within 75 miles of an employee's worksite from 50 to 15 employees. Additionally, H.R. 5496 aimed to amend the hours-of-service requirement by removing the reference to "1,250 hours of service" and including part-time and full-time employees as "eligible employees." Two bills proposed new eligibility requirements for certain veterans with service-connected disabilities and education support professionals. The bill proposed new eligibility requirements for veterans with service-connected disabilities, allowing them to access FMLA-protected leave with reduced employment requirements based on their disability rating. Veterans with a 30%-50% disability rating would need 8 months of employment and 833 hours worked, while those with a 60% or higher rating would need 6 months of employment and 625 hours worked. Certification from a VA medical provider or approved non-VA facility would be required for leave related to their disability. Employees with service-connected disabilities rated at 30% or higher must provide certification from a VA medical provider or approved non-VA facility for medical leave. Veterans with disabilities rated at 30%-50% need 8 months of employment and 833 hours worked, while those with 60% or higher need 6 months of employment. S. 3444 would have allowed veterans with service-connected disabilities to use FMLA leave sooner by adjusting the hours-of-service requirement based on their disability rating. Veterans rated at 30% or higher would need 8 months of employment and 833 hours worked, while those with a rating of 60% or higher would only need 6 months of employment. Additionally, certification from the Department of Defense would be required for veterans with disabilities rated at 30% or higher at the time of retirement. S. 3444 allowed veterans with service-connected disabilities to access FMLA leave sooner by adjusting the hours-of-service requirement. It also proposed creating a separate hours-of-service requirement for educational support professionals. The proposal would have required employees to work a minimum of 60 hours per month or 60% of the total monthly hours expected for their job. It also aimed to create separate rules for calculating leave entitlement for educational support professionals.
